quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: ... early days, it's very important to just go back to the basics, build the skeleton before you put on the makeup.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for prioritizing foundational growth work before scaling tactics.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: So the first question I would ask is, do you have a website? Is it fast? Do the search engine knows that it exists?
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: A practical diagnostic checklist for early growth readiness focused on fundamentals and discoverability.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Only after all of those questions are answered, should you then consider, do I have money? Can I put it behind some paid ads to make sure people come to my website?
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: A sequencing framework that argues for earning organic discoverability before spending on paid acquisition.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: You can't run a successful paid ads program if you have a website that's loading in four plus seconds.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: A concrete performance threshold that ties site speed directly to paid growth effectiveness.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: They went from $0 in revenue to a mind-boggling $300 million in revenue in three years, while also staying EBITDA positive.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A standout growth data point that sets the stakes for why Deel’s approach is worth studying.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: The best way to see what Miro is all about and how it can help your team collaborate better is not to listen to me talk about it, but to go check it out for yourself, go to miro.com/lenny.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A practical go-to-market lesson: drive adoption by getting users hands-on with the product rather than relying on explanation.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With the help of the Miro team, I created a super cool Miro board with two of my own favorite templates, my one pager template and my managing up template that you can plug and play and start using immediately with your team.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Shows an actionable distribution tactic: ship ready-to-use templates so teams can realize value immediately (“plug and play”).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Miro is a killer tool for brainstorming with your team, laying out your strategy, sharing user research findings, capturing ideas, giving feedback on wireframes, and generally just collaborating with your colleagues.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete checklist of high-value collaboration use cases practitioners can map to their own workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: LMNT is a tasty electrolyte drink mix with a science-backed electrolyte ratio.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a positioning approach—anchor product differentiation in a specific, credibility-boosting claim (“science-backed ratio”).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You can try LMNT totally risk-free. If you don't like it, you can share it with a salty friend and they'll give you your money back no questions asked.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A clear conversion lever: reduce purchase friction with an explicit, no-questions-asked guarantee and a playful sharing fallback.

quotes.topic_title: Deel overview and growth trajectory stats
quotes.text: Deel is payroll, HR, and compliance platform for global teams.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: A crisp positioning statement that clearly defines Deel’s category and core value proposition.

quotes.topic_title: Deel overview and growth trajectory stats
quotes.text: And when I joined Deel, actually that was around July, 2020, we were less than a million dollars in ARR. And then over time, within the first year on January, 2021, we were at $4 million ARR. We finished 2021 with 57 million. April '22, we were looking at a hundred million. And then we started off this year with $295 million in ARR.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: Concrete milestone-by-milestone ARR trajectory that benchmarks what “extraordinary growth” looks like in practice.

quotes.topic_title: Deel overview and growth trajectory stats
quotes.text: And what we're particularly proud of is that we've been EBITDA positive.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: Highlights a counterpoint to the common “growth at all costs” narrative: scaling rapidly while staying profitable.

quotes.topic_title: Deel overview and growth trajectory stats
quotes.text: I was the second hire to the marketing team, and I was I believe either employee 19 or 20 on the overall Deel team.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: Gives practitioners a concrete sense of how early “early” is when joining (or building) a hypergrowth company.

quotes.topic_title: Deel overview and growth trajectory stats
quotes.text: So Ramp was the first one to be crowned the fastest growing, and then we took that crown from them.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: A memorable competitive benchmark that frames Deel’s growth in relative, market-wide terms.

quotes.topic_title: Cheap growth channels: communities and answering questions
quotes.text: So those cheaper channels are often places where people are just trying to get an answer to their question.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: Defines a practical mental model for “cheap growth”: go where users are actively seeking help, not where you can broadcast ads.

quotes.topic_title: Cheap growth channels: communities and answering questions
quotes.text: That's, when you think about cheap channels, that's a really good place to start, is just add value to people, answer their questions.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for community/SEO-led growth: lead with problem-solving rather than selling.

quotes.topic_title: Cheap growth channels: communities and answering questions
quotes.text: You don't necessarily have to advertise, when you go to Reddit and you set up those keywords to be tracking when people ask certain questions, you're not paying any money to do that.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: Concrete tactic: keyword-monitor Reddit to find high-intent questions and respond without paid spend.

quotes.topic_title: Cheap growth channels: communities and answering questions
quotes.text: It's important to notice that if you're looking at a subreddit of about a thousand people, recognize the upper size of this audience, you're not going to win 5,000 businesses through that Reddit community, but you're maybe going to win 10% of the people there that are having this problem.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: A quantitative sanity check for “cheap channels”: evaluate audience size and realistic conversion ceilings before investing.

quotes.topic_title: Cheap growth channels: communities and answering questions
quotes.text: but if people aren't asking this question to Google, you can write all the content you want, it doesn't matter, nobody's going to find it.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: Contrarian warning against blind content production: SEO only works when there’s existing search demand.

quotes.topic_title: How to respond: value-first, never automated
quotes.text: But the value-add way would be explaining what the solution to that problem is. Because the reality is there are a lot of people out there who can probably solve this, and then providing your solution, but answer their question first, and then let them decide if they want to come with you or go with someone else.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: A clear value-first engagement framework: fully solve the user’s problem before mentioning your product, and let them choose.

quotes.topic_title: How to respond: value-first, never automated
quotes.text: But the whole point of someone asking a question isn't to be sold a solution. It's like, "I just need an answer." So genuinely treat this person like a friend of yours, answer their question, be like, "Yes, it's doable. No, it's not doable. Yes, you can do it, but you need to consider X, Y, Z. If you want to learn more about it, you can chat with us."
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: Practical guidance for writing responses that feel human and helpful rather than salesy, with a simple script practitioners can reuse.

quotes.topic_title: How to respond: value-first, never automated
quotes.text: It was never automated. It still isn't today. We would never automate our interactions with people.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: A strong, counter-norm stance against automating community engagement, emphasizing trust and authenticity as a growth lever.

quotes.topic_title: How to respond: value-first, never automated
quotes.text: So early days, it was myself, the other people on my team, our co-founders, which to this day they still do by the way. So it's a lot of people on the team. Every single person on the team has access to these. And whoever is the first person to jump in will flag it.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: An operational model for scaling community responses: broad internal access, founders participating, and a “first to jump in flags it” workflow.

quotes.topic_title: How to respond: value-first, never automated
quotes.text: So early on that was more close to 80% to 90%. But that number has grown. Again, the net number has grown, but the percentage of the overall value has shrunk because other channels have also grown significantly.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: A concrete data point on channel mix over time and a useful reminder that percentages can shrink even as absolute impact grows.

quotes.topic_title: SEO principles: end the search, not keyword stuffing
quotes.text: But the main thing to think about it is, is the Google search over? If someone reads your content, if they typed in something to Google, and then they read the article that you've published, are they going back to Google to continue reading more or is the Google search over?
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: A simple litmus test for SEO content quality: success means fully resolving the user’s query so they don’t keep searching.

quotes.topic_title: SEO principles: end the search, not keyword stuffing
quotes.text: Because ultimately that's what the search engines care about is, I want to make sure this person gets their answer quickest way possible.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: Reframes SEO from keyword tactics to optimizing for fast, complete answers aligned with search engine goals.

quotes.topic_title: SEO principles: end the search, not keyword stuffing
quotes.text: So asking that question of, is the search over is a really good place to start, instead of just shoving keywords.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for practitioners: prioritize ending the search over keyword stuffing when drafting content.

quotes.topic_title: SEO principles: end the search, not keyword stuffing
quotes.text: So we do very well in explaining to people what EOR is and isn't and what its limitations are. Because the first question that you will have after the EOR question's answered is, okay, what's the downside? When do I need to not use it?
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: Concrete example of “ending the search” by covering definitions plus limitations and downsides to preempt follow-up queries.

quotes.topic_title: SEO principles: end the search, not keyword stuffing
quotes.text: But we have this framework that we call the traffic light system. Essentially we go, whenever the team is going to do a content series, they will go and find up to 700 keywords.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: Introduces a scalable operational methodology for SEO planning, including a specific scope (“up to 700 keywords”).

quotes.topic_title: SEO operations: traffic-light keyword framework and tooling
quotes.text: But we have this framework that we call the traffic light system. Essentially we go, whenever the team is going to do a content series, they will go and find up to 700 keywords.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: Introduces a scalable, repeatable keyword-ops framework for planning SEO content series.

quotes.topic_title: SEO operations: traffic-light keyword framework and tooling
quotes.text: So with that, you get the green light ones, which is the intent is very high, this person wants our solution. The yellow light is intent, could be they are a 50:50, maybe they're looking to buy our solution, maybe it's not soon enough. And then the red is, this person is not looking to buy our solution, they're just doing this search for any other reason.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: Defines an intent-based prioritization model that prevents teams from wasting effort on low-conversion queries.

quotes.topic_title: SEO operations: traffic-light keyword framework and tooling
quotes.text: So one of the examples that I always give people of when you type EOR into Google, it doesn't give you employer of record, it gives you enhanced oil recovery, because most of the people typing EOR to Google is looking for that solution.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: A concrete SERP-intent example showing why keyword assumptions can be wrong and why checking Google’s current results matters.

quotes.topic_title: SEO operations: traffic-light keyword framework and tooling
quotes.text: Oftentimes the bottom part of Google where it says, the next questions that you should be asking is a really good place to go to understand, okay, after someone's done with this search, what's the next question that they ask? And the next one and the next one.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: Gives a practical tactic for mining related questions to shape content depth and internal topic coverage.

quotes.topic_title: SEO operations: traffic-light keyword framework and tooling
quotes.text: I almost think of keywords as like, that's your address, that's how you give Google, please send people my way.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for on-page keyword usage as discoverability infrastructure rather than mere repetition.

quotes.topic_title: Content team structure and publishing cadence
quotes.text: We have one person that is in charge of all of the operations. So that is working with our freelancers, making sure that the briefs are sent out, making sure that the fact checking is done on time, that the articles are published on the website, and tracking and everything, they run the machinery on the backend.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: Highlights a scalable content-org model: a dedicated ops owner to systematize execution and quality control.

quotes.topic_title: Content team structure and publishing cadence
quotes.text: The biggest mistake people make is SEO is one of those things that, you can try and automate it, you can do a lot of things that save you time, but it never stops being time-consuming. And to do it well, it is going to be time-consuming.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: A practical warning that SEO success requires sustained manual effort, not just tooling or automation.

quotes.topic_title: Content team structure and publishing cadence
quotes.text: So oftentimes people just get over it or they think it's below them to be going over and doing keyword research and doing all of those things one by one. And that's oftentimes where people lose out is they try to cut corners.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: Contrarian reminder that seniority can create blind spots—skipping fundamentals is a common failure mode in SEO.

quotes.topic_title: Content team structure and publishing cadence
quotes.text: We used to put out about 10 articles a week, that's net new. Whereas now we are doing more of five new articles and five article updates.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: Concrete cadence shift that practitioners can copy: balance new publishing with systematic updating to maintain rankings and accuracy.

quotes.topic_title: Content team structure and publishing cadence
quotes.text: Because the type of content we write, regulations change, things change all the time, so we need to make sure that even if something was published two years ago, it's up-to-date. So we have a team that is responsible for continuously fact checking.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: Operationalizes content quality for regulated/fast-changing domains by making continuous fact-checking a standing responsibility.

quotes.topic_title: When SEO makes sense (and when it doesn’t)
quotes.text: I don't think everybody should be doing SEO.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: A contrarian stance that challenges the default assumption that SEO is universally beneficial.

quotes.topic_title: When SEO makes sense (and when it doesn’t)
quotes.text: I think if you are in a space where people are looking for a solution, you should be doing SEO.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: A simple decision rule: invest in SEO when search intent indicates active problem-solving behavior.

quotes.topic_title: When SEO makes sense (and when it doesn’t)
quotes.text: But if you are a direct to consumer company selling people lipstick, which I'm a huge buyer of, you probably shouldn't invest in SEO all that much because people don't go to Google for that.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: A concrete example showing how channel choice should follow real discovery behavior, not generic best practices.

quotes.topic_title: When SEO makes sense (and when it doesn’t)
quotes.text: They go to Instagram, they go to influencers.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: Highlights an alternative acquisition channel when discovery is social-led rather than search-led.

quotes.topic_title: When SEO makes sense (and when it doesn’t)
quotes.text: But if you are in a space which most B2B products tend to be, that you're solving an active problem very specifically, then I would say SEO is a good idea.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: Connects SEO effectiveness to B2B’s high-intent, specific problem queries—useful for prioritizing growth channels.

quotes.topic_title: Early growth prioritization: fundamentals before paid
quotes.text: Yes. So I would say early days, it's very important to just go back to the basics, build the skeleton before you put on the makeup.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for prioritizing foundational growth work before scaling tactics.

quotes.topic_title: Early growth prioritization: fundamentals before paid
quotes.text: So the first question I would ask is, do you have a website? Is it fast? Do the search engine knows that it exists? Okay, great. The next step would be, can people find it? If they can't find it, you need to write content to make sure that people can find it.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: A step-by-step early growth checklist that starts with site performance and discoverability before anything else.

quotes.topic_title: Early growth prioritization: fundamentals before paid
quotes.text: But you can't run a successful paid ads program if you have a website that's loading in four plus seconds.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: A concrete, counterintuitive constraint that reframes paid growth as downstream of core product/website experience.

quotes.topic_title: Early growth prioritization: fundamentals before paid
quotes.text: But then if your one-liner can also work for another business, please don't let that be your one-liner.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: Practical positioning advice for avoiding generic B2B messaging that fails to differentiate or clarify value.

quotes.topic_title: Early growth prioritization: fundamentals before paid
quotes.text: Our website was hard coded, so the first thing we did with the help of the dev team was to move it to a platform that it was easy for me to access and edit, so that we could continuously A/B test things.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: A specific example of investing in growth velocity by enabling rapid iteration and A/B testing.

quotes.topic_title: Paid growth expansion: long-tail channels and diversification
quotes.text: So those are the platforms that individually never contribute a significant enough chunk for you to individually care about it. But if you add them up, it diversifies your lead flow such that it ends up being about 30% of your overall lead flow that's coming in.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: A clear long-tail paid growth framework with a concrete benchmark (30% of leads) for why small channels matter in aggregate.

quotes.topic_title: Paid growth expansion: long-tail channels and diversification
quotes.text: When you run an individual podcast ad, yeah, you're probably not going to get 2000 customers from one podcast. But you run 10 of those and then it starts adding up.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: Practical guidance for scaling long-tail channels via volume rather than expecting any single placement to be a breakout winner.

quotes.topic_title: Paid growth expansion: long-tail channels and diversification
quotes.text: And we started going very niche with websites that have maybe 50,000, a hundred thousand visitors a month, which isn't all that much when you're thinking about your paid ad strategy.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: A specific example of what “niche” looks like in practice, helping teams define the long-tail inventory they should test.

quotes.topic_title: Paid growth expansion: long-tail channels and diversification
quotes.text: Our paid ads team, they spent just as much time running Facebook and Google ads as they do running those third party, much smaller platform ads. It takes the same effort, but you need to have a diversified source of your leads.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: Counterintuitive operational reality: small channels can require the same setup effort as major platforms, so diversification must be intentional.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you're looking to build AI powered features in your audio and video products, then you need to know about AssemblyAI, which makes it easy to transcribe and understand speech at scale.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Clear positioning statement that translates a broad goal (AI features) into a concrete capability (speech transcription/understanding) and scale requirement.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: What I love about AssemblyAI is you can use their simple API to access the latest AI breakthroughs from top tier research labs.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a build-vs-buy mental model: leverage APIs to productize cutting-edge research without building models in-house.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Product teams and startups and enterprises are using AssemblyAI to automatically transcribe and summarize phone calls and virtual meetings, detect topics in podcasts, pinpoint when sensitive content is spoken and lots more.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a practical menu of high-value audio AI use cases teams can copy (summarization, topic detection, sensitive-content detection).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: All of AssemblyAI's models, which are accessed through their API, are production ready.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable procurement/build criterion: prioritize “production ready” models to reduce deployment risk and time-to-value.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I know you're not a big fan of awareness campaigns and marketing campaigns, especially early on, and so I'd love to get your perspective on why that is and how you think about that sort of investment?
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Introduces a contrarian growth prompt—questioning early awareness spend in favor of more measurable investment approaches.

quotes.topic_title: Why early B2B awareness campaigns often waste time
quotes.text: I'm not a huge fan of early awareness campaigns for B2B businesses specifically.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: A contrarian stance that sets up her broader argument for prioritizing conversion-ready demand over early brand spend in B2B.

quotes.topic_title: Why early B2B awareness campaigns often waste time
quotes.text: Because B2B businesses uniquely are started because there's a very real need and there's a lot of people that are ready to convert, first tap into the bottom of the funnel, and then go out and start speaking to the masses.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: A practical sequencing framework: exhaust bottom-of-funnel demand before investing in broad awareness.

quotes.topic_title: Why early B2B awareness campaigns often waste time
quotes.text: But I promise you it'll probably take you six to eight months minimum to tap into that bottom of the funnel of people that are ready to convert today before you have to start doing awareness ads out there.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: A concrete timing heuristic practitioners can use to delay awareness spend until conversion-ready demand is saturated.

quotes.topic_title: Why early B2B awareness campaigns often waste time
quotes.text: That's not to say never do awareness ads, but it's oftentimes the shiny, cool thing that you want to do and it just ends up being a waste of time early on.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: A warning against premature brand campaigns driven by novelty rather than proven messaging and demand capture.

quotes.topic_title: Why early B2B awareness campaigns often waste time
quotes.text: I've seen Notion do a great job with their out-of-home ads. They didn't do it early on, they started doing it much later in their journey by the time when everybody that was working in tech knew what it was, and it was really to drive home the message continuously rather than to introduce themselves to the world.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: A specific example showing awareness works best as reinforcement once the market already recognizes the product.

quotes.topic_title: Partnership strategy: trusted advisors vs audience overlap
quotes.text: Yeah, I would say it is very important to know who you should partner with. So there's two groups of partners.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: Introduces a simple partnership segmentation framework that guides how to prioritize partner types.

quotes.topic_title: Partnership strategy: trusted advisors vs audience overlap
quotes.text: People oftentimes end up partnering with any company that has a shared audience. Decent place to start. But just because you share an audience doesn't mean your audience goes to your partner for guidance when they have this problem.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: Challenges the common “audience overlap” approach by adding the critical filter of decision-time trust and guidance-seeking behavior.

quotes.topic_title: Partnership strategy: trusted advisors vs audience overlap
quotes.text: So in our case, venture capital partners was a huge one because when you get money from a new VC, they ask, they're like, "Okay, thank you for giving us this money, now we want to expand our team with the money you gave us. What are your other portfolio companies using? What is a platform that you trust that you would recommend?"
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: Gives a concrete, high-leverage partner example (VCs) and the exact “recommendation” moment that drives referrals.

quotes.topic_title: Partnership strategy: trusted advisors vs audience overlap
quotes.text: So it's important to not only recognize the importance of an audience overlap as well as whether or not those people are seen as a trusted resource for the solution you are putting out there.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: Summarizes the actionable partner selection criteria: overlap plus perceived trust as a source for the specific decision.

quotes.topic_title: Customer questions Deel answers: compliance, taxes, hiring specifics
quotes.text: So when you are an HR leader or a finance leader or a legal leader in a company that works let's say in America, but you want to hire someone in another country, you don't know what you don't know.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: Highlights the core customer pain (unknown unknowns) that high-intent content and expert guidance should target in complex domains like cross-border hiring.

quotes.topic_title: Customer questions Deel answers: compliance, taxes, hiring specifics
quotes.text: That's why we have in-house experts that answer those questions, that constantly provide updates if the answer to that question has changed over time, which regulations constantly change. An answer we provided a week ago may change, and you need to be very proactive in communicating that.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: Actionable operating model: pair expert-backed answers with continuous updates and proactive communication in fast-changing regulatory environments.

quotes.topic_title: Customer questions Deel answers: compliance, taxes, hiring specifics
quotes.text: So for us, they're very nitty-gritty and use case specific. The taxes you need to pay for someone who is an engineer that's a full-time employee might be very different than who is a designer who is a contractor.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: Emphasizes that the highest-converting questions are specific to role and worker type—guidance for structuring content and product flows around concrete scenarios.

quotes.topic_title: Customer questions Deel answers: compliance, taxes, hiring specifics
quotes.text: Rarely the question is what's the best payroll solution?
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: Contrarian reminder that customers don’t start with category comparisons; they start with urgent, situational problems that the product must resolve.

quotes.topic_title: Customer questions Deel answers: compliance, taxes, hiring specifics
quotes.text: And created this resource for our own customers because we just wanted to help them. And then it ended up being such a good resource that it was linked from the IRS's website being like, "If you have questions, check out this article," which was a great moment of pride.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: Concrete example of “be the best answer” content earning authoritative distribution (IRS link), validating helpfulness as a growth lever.

quotes.topic_title: Paid acquisition best practices: creative fatigue and true ROI
quotes.text: So creative fatigue is a real thing. When you put an ad out there that works for three weeks, people get tired of seeing that, you need to constantly update that.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: Highlights the practical need for a continuous creative refresh cadence to prevent performance decay in paid channels.

quotes.topic_title: Paid acquisition best practices: creative fatigue and true ROI
quotes.text: So our paid team is actually updating the ads we put out there on a monthly basis with the exception of a few Google ads, which need to be straight to the point.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: Gives a concrete operating rhythm (monthly refresh) plus a channel-specific exception practitioners can copy.

quotes.topic_title: Paid acquisition best practices: creative fatigue and true ROI
quotes.text: But then you ask that question to sales teams and they're like, "Yeah, I'm busy, but none of these are converting."
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: Challenges the common “more leads = success” assumption by surfacing the sales-side reality of low-quality lead volume.

quotes.topic_title: Paid acquisition best practices: creative fatigue and true ROI
quotes.text: So it's really important to look at not just the volume that you bring in, but what is the journey of that volume with your business one year out. How much money do you actually make from them to be able to properly decide how much can I spend to win this customer?
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: Provides a clear ROI/payback framework: optimize spend based on downstream conversion and 1-year value, not top-of-funnel metrics.

quotes.topic_title: Paid acquisition best practices: creative fatigue and true ROI
quotes.text: We know an average customer that comes from a Facebook ad, at what rate do they converge from a lead to a qualified opportunity to a closed on.? And then on average, how much money do we make from that customer one year out.
quotes.speaker: Meltem Kuran Berkowitz
quotes.context: Describes a measurable methodology for channel evaluation using funnel conversion rates and 1-year value by source (e.g., Facebook).
